text:

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

GUEST SPEAKER 1: And a lot
of the women in this field, about 20 of them, are
part of this co-op called

the Solar Women of Totogalpa. And these women,
basically, they get grants from different
funding sources

to research sustainable
energy options. So one of the
things that they do is they make their
own solar panels.

And the people in
the village can buy these either with
money or with hours spent working in the co-op.

So we decided that even though
they're making 60-watt panels--

does not match that--
but even though they're making 60-watt
panels like these, they also all have cell
phones, but a lot of them

are off the grid. So they also need ways
of charging these, and we thought that solar power
was a good way of doing this.

So what they're doing right
now to make these is-- this is a poor image.

But basically, they take
the smaller cells, which are 8 by 15 centimeters,
and these are rejects,

so they're not as
efficient as standard cells that we might use here,
but they're much cheaper,

so they use those. They might hand solder
them all together and line them up, put
liquid silicone over them,

and then put a glass piece over
it, and then encapsulate it all and make it look much
nicer like the ones you

saw in the previous slide. So this is a much
smaller, much nicer

looking one that is made
in China and imported, but it's available
for $20 in Managua, which is about three hours
from the town we stayed in.

And so these are very
difficult to get, and they're pretty
expensive, but they also would like to be
able to make them

there so that it's
about the same price, but it's more accessible.

It employs some people, and
it's just more sustainable. So that's what we set out to do.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: So
as was mentioned, they do have access
to solar cells,

but unfortunately,
what happens right now is to make the
cell phone charger, they need to cut these cells.

And what they do is, basically,
they cut one of these cells into four parts and then
attach them in series so that the voltages add up,
so you can get up to 6 volts.

Unfortunately,
with this process, what ends up happening is you
end up using a lot of the cells just because the method
that they use to cut them

is not foolproof, and so you end
up cracking a lot of the cells. And when you talk
to them, we realized

that they waste about
half the cells they cut, which means that if they
needed to use 9 cells,

they'd end up using 18
because they'd waste half. And so we figured that if
we could somehow step up

the voltage given by
three original cells, they called these original
cells, if you could step up the voltage given by
three original cells

to the required 5
volts to charge a cell phone without cutting
them, it would save them a lot of time and money.

And so what we decided to do
was connect three of these cells in series, so you get
a 1.5-volt output.

And then have that output run
through your circuit, which steps it up to 5 volts.

Now, the circuit
basically works like this. So this is your input.

You have current inputting
data at 1.5 volts. It goes through
your op amp and then

steps it up to 1.25
or 3.3, depending

on how it's connected. For our purposes, we needed 5,
so we connected it accordingly.

These are capacitors, an
inductor, and a zener diode. The zener diode is used to
make sure that the voltage goes in one direction only.

And so basically,
these two leads have a voltage difference
of 5 volts across them

when connected to the solar
panels and up in the lighting. And what we did was, we then--

so this is we surveyed what
kind of cell phones are these and realized that, for the
most part, they're Nokias,

and this is the most common
type of phone that's available there. And we got the adapter that
they used to charge this,

cut out the phone,
and attached it here. If you look at our
prototype, you notice that.

So the orange and black
wires are these, basically, and then they
connect to your port.

And then basically, the idea
is that you plug it in, put it

on sunlight, and
use this as a way to make sure that you're
always facing the sun openly.

But there are a lot of
notches along the sides.

And so basically,
you wedge this in, and then you can change
the angle of your panel.

So this is just a very
rudimentary cost breakdown

of what we estimate our cell
phone charger to cost them.

Basically, I mean, finally,
this is the number that we came.

We were trying to shoot for $20,
and we're slightly above that. But we figure that there's
two ways to optimize costs,

and that is very viable for
them to get this for $20.

Yeah, basically, this is
just to give you an idea how expensive the
components are. I don't want to run through
each one of them just like--

GUEST SPEAKER 3: I'm
sorry, just to mention a really quick thing. We're also including
$4 for labor,

so even though it
is produced locally and it is providing employment,
whereas the internet,

the China made one is not
providing any employment for the community. GUEST SPEAKER 2: Right. Exactly. China made one cell
for $80, but they

don't provide any
source of income to the people in Managua.

And so this is just to give you
an idea of the cost breakdown.

This is just a
blown-up image of us. Again, just to give you an idea
of the components that we used.

Essentially, this circuit is
enclosed by this casing right

here. So it's that circuit
basically, underneath this. GUEST SPEAKER 1: Which
you can see here.

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
Which you can see that in that image, the
next image right there.

So I mean, like I said,
this is your output from the solar cells,
which go into the circuit

and then go and
charge the cell phone. And the actual
circuitry, so this

to talking about why we
made circuits like this. We decided to use a
breadboard because when

you talk to Mario, who's
our community funder, is one of the
community partners,

he told us that they do
have access to breadboards, but don't have access to proto
boards, which we were initially

fine on using. And so we decided to stick
with the breadboard, the model. And we also, we figured
the [INAUDIBLE],,

the various components,
and they are available. The only component
that we potentially

see having to be
shipped there is this. But since they already
ship solar cells,

it would just be another
added component to ship, and it's not very
good quality, so we think it's definitely viable.

So that's why we decided to
go with the breadboard design. Apart from that-- do you
want to talk about this?

GUEST SPEAKER 3: But
before that, I just wanted to just speak a little
bit about the [INAUDIBLE],, in general, why we chose
to build it the way we did.

First of all, it's
made out of wood because they're really
locally-found material.

So first of all, I'll talk
about the solar panel. So this is a solar panel.

Because we didn't have,
I guess, easy access to the liquid silicone and
aluminum and plastics to use,

we still use acrylic
and a different method to glue the cells.

In Nicaragua, they
make these differently, and they customize it
for every application.

And so when we were talking
to him on the phone, he already had to made some
changes to the initial design and we had made, and he said
he would change the hinges

and everything. And so it would be
made out of aluminum. And so originally, we
wanted to make leg stands

so we could change the
angle and not just here. But then we realized
that it might be easier

to put something in here
instead of having to have legs. So we just came up with the
notches and cut a PCV pipe.

And then you can
change the angle. Moreover, we wanted to create
a way to protect the circuit, so we just encased it
around this aluminum frame

with the two wires hanging out. Additionally, these are
really easy to switch, so if you do have
another cell phone,

you could switch the charger
into some other cell phone. And another reason why
this is over here, just

in case of rain. I mean, hopefully,
you have it outside, and you'll be looking at us. Because it rains,
this is waterproof,

and it will also
protects the cell phone and the charger for at
least enough time for you to come and get it.

If it's raining really hard and
breaks, it's going to get wet. For the long time, we realized
it really should be protected.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: Right. And like Juan
said, we could also

have another adapter going
out from the same leads. And we actually do
have a USB adapter that runs at the same
voltage that we did test.

But for the purpose
of the demonstration, we decided to go with the Nokia
just because it's the more

locally available phone. But we could potentially have
a number of different adapters shooting out here.

It's all run on
the same voltage.

GUEST SPEAKER 3: So we're doing
some testing in the past couple of days to see how much
power we could get out

of the cell phone, using
the lamp over there, you can test it. Make sure you have a
demo card, actually,

at work because it does work. GUEST SPEAKER 2: Do
you want to actually-- I don't think it's
going to stretch.

Do you want to just get this? GUEST SPEAKER 3: So
here is the solar panel.

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
That's all right. GUEST SPEAKER 3: Can make
it incident to the light.
And you connect it.

They're charging? So it does work? You get scared for
a second there.

GUEST SPEAKER 1: Well, there's
no way to stay charging. It just has a little
charging symbol. GUEST SPEAKER 3:
Yeah, so it does work.

However, we wanted to
see how efficient it is and how fast we could
get it to actually work.

We realized that Boston-made
sun is not the same as Nicaragua

sun on the equator. So we conducted-- there
are different lights

and light outputs. This is the output power of
the light of the solar panels

calculated by just measuring
the current and the voltage at the same time
as the solar panel. GUEST SPEAKER 1: [INAUDIBLE].

GUEST SPEAKER 3: And
the output power, it's output power
are at least two leads, calculated by measuring
the current and the voltage
at the same time. So we are getting this.

So we then make a standard
for the efficiency,

and this is for the past
percent of the power we're getting right now. If we estimate for
Nicaraguan sun,

we would be getting
around 65% efficiency. Right now, we're getting
about 0.2 amps in Boston.

I mean, 200-- GUEST SPEAKER 1: No. GUEST SPEAKER 3: 0.02 amps,
20 milliamps in Boston.

if we extrapolated for
how we were getting in Nicaragua with the
power in Nicaragua, we'd be getting around--

GUEST SPEAKER 1: 80 to 100. GUEST SPEAKER 3: --80
to 100 milliamps, which in the cell phone
batteries are about 800--

GUEST SPEAKER 1:
Yeah, 800 milliamps. GUEST SPEAKER 3: 800 milliamps. So it would take about 10 hours
to charge the cell phone, which

is not ideal because
we were aiming for, at the beginning was-- GUEST SPEAKER 1: Five-ish. GUEST SPEAKER 3: Four
hours, five hours.

We're expecting 200. The circuit said that
200 milliamps would be outputted from the circuit.

But instead, we're
getting 9 to 100. So it's not as efficient
as we would like,

but it still worked. GUEST SPEAKER 2: Right. And just to explain why it's
so scattered at a point,

actually, above the 100%
efficiency mark, which is theoretically possible, but
there was probably something

ahead of-- GUEST SPEAKER 1:
One of the times we were using the actual sun. And so it probably changed
a little bit in between.
GUEST SPEAKER 3: [INAUDIBLE].  That's it. Thank you very much.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: Thank you. Do you guys have any questions? AUDIENCE: So how did you
estimate the Nicaraguan sun?

GUEST SPEAKER 1: We
took measurements while we were there as far as
what voltage and current output each cell was at
around 1 o'clock.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: [INAUDIBLE]
based on what we think, how much sun that
would relate it.

AUDIENCE: With
the 10-hour issue,

the only thing I think of is
the sun moves in 10 hours, so the user would have to
understand that they would have

to move the-- so it might actually be
longer than 10 hours. An optimal sun is 10 hours.

So it might be more like-- GUEST SPEAKER 1: The
one thing we noticed was when talking to
people, they usually didn't actually charge it
from completely discharged

to charged. They usually charge
from about half charge, so it would be more
like five hours, which is more reasonable. Because that's
more like the band

that sun is usable in a day. AUDIENCE: How long is the
cell phone value life?

GUEST SPEAKER 1: We got
mixed answers on that. We did about 10 to 15
interviews of people and ask that question, and most
people, I think, on average

said they charged it
about once a week. There was one person who
said once every 15 days, one said every three days.

It just depends on
how much they use it. GUEST SPEAKER 2:
It also, I think, depends on how many cell
phones they have in the family.

Because we noticed that
some family had one cell phone for the entire
family, so it, obviously, drained out faster.

But if you have
individual cell phones, they tend to last longer
because you don't need--

and so it really depends. But for the most
part, like we said, I feel once a week was a
very reasonable-- maybe twice

a week, I guess, on average. Not if they don't use it a lot. GUEST SPEAKER 1: And
most of them just-- we noticed just from
living with the families,

a lot of the times, the cell
phone just stays at the house so that if they receive a call. So they can actually
still be using it

while it's charged
because they'll be within hearing shots. So if they get a call, they
can unplug it and answer it, but they can't call it with
it while it's charging.

GUEST SPEAKER 2: I
mean, essentially, they use a lot of cell
phone as land lines

just because they don't
have landline connectivity. So yeah.

GUEST SPEAKER 4: Just a little
bit about the community partner we worked with, they
are called Asaprosar. They're a human development
NGO based in Santa Ana.

They work in rural areas and try
to improve the quality of life through environmental and
nutritional education, also

micro-credit opportunities and
general community development. One of Asaprosar's
current projects

is introducing rice
cultivation in El Salvador, both as a source of nutrition,
but also, as income generation.

And in order to prepare
rice for consumption, it needs to be threshed
and also dehusked.

And current methods
that the community uses are very time and
money intensive. So our design
challenge is to develop

a cheap and local process that
dehusks rice more successfully and conveniently.

The most important product
attributes that we focused on are the efficiency and the
affordability of the product.

Our goal was to make sure
that more than 90% of the rice was successfully
dehusked, while keeping

the price of the
product under $2. We also looked at cost
and durability and safety

of the product. And so after extensive
research and some brainstorming exercises, we concluded that
the best approach to this design

challenge is to modify
an existing molino, which is a corn mill currently
used in the communities.

The advantages are that
it's already available, and it's being supplied
by our community partner.

And essentially,
what we're proposing is inserting another material
between the two metal plates of the molino that
would provide enough friction

to dehusk the rice grain,
but at the same time, prevent them from being broken.

And some of the challenges
that we're dealing with are the lack of precision
of the molino and then

also the fact that
it has friction so that it wears
the materials down.

GUEST SPEAKER 5: So I'm going to
talk about the experimentation process. So initially, our
first problem was

to decide on what kind of
insert we wanted to use. So we looked at metal, various
types of rubber and foam

and leather. And when we were looking
at these materials, we really evaluated
them on the cost,

how much residue do they were
going to leave on the rice, how long it was going
to last, or how durable and how available
the material was.

So when we did our experiments,
our two main variables that we were looking
at were, essentially,

the type of material and also
the tightness of the molino. So essentially, the
tightness was how much space was going to exist
in between the insert

and the metal plates to
provide the adequate function. And when we did our methodology,
our experiments, first, we

inserted the material, and
we controlled the spacing by screwing the tab
all the way in so we

couldn't turn it any tighter. And then we turned it a certain
number of turns back out, so we knew how
much space existed

in between the
[INAUDIBLE] and the space. And then we ran the
rice through the molino, and after we ran the rice
through, we winnowed it,

and we separated
the rice into husk. But when it was
still husk and if it had been dehusked or broken
or the rice particles

or the leftover husk,
so the three particles we were left with. And these pictures
show the various types

of experiments we really did and
was quite an extensive process. We experimented with various
different types of materials.

We would use one material and
varied the number of turns. We might insert multiple
layers of the material

to see if that changed anything. And also, we would run
the material, the rice through twice and see if
that changed the efficiency

of the rice itself. And ultimately,
what we decided was that leather was the most
appropriate insert for us.

Because when we did
different material inserts, we, essentially, found out that
it wasn't so much the material

that matters, but
it was the number of turns that was really-- when changed the process
and the efficiency.

And we knew that
this material had to be soft enough so that
the frictional and the torque

wouldn't break the material. But we also knew it had to be
very durable because we didn't want it to wear away, so leather
was the best option for us.

GUEST SPEAKER 6: So when
we're looking at leather, we first decided that we
wanted to do unattached,

and it had pretty
similar results, and it wasn't hazardous if
we're not using some toxic glue.

We also decided with
brown, organic leather. We didn't want anything that
was too processed or patented

or anything. And we thought that one
piece might be acceptable. Because it was similar,
we had similar results

on two or more pieces. It's obviously cheaper,
if it's [INAUDIBLE] and it's less hazardous if we're
not [INAUDIBLE] around here

together again. So we actually were
worried about toxicity after we learned about
tanning those kind of chemical

intensive. We concluded though that
there is no dangerous exposure because chromium 6 is the
most hazardous chemical that's

being used in treatment. And it's actually broken
down into chromium 3, which is an essential nutrient in
your body, so when it's inhaled,

it's OK. OSHA says that 100 micrograms
of chromium protein or drinking

water is acceptable. We found that that's
equivalent to eating seven of these inserts a
day, so we don't think

anyoe is going to do that. We also found that
there's not really significant leather ware.

We process about 7/2
kilograms of rice, which is a family's roughly rice
consumption using this concert,

and I'll pass this
around, but this is a new one compared to
that one that we processed.

So you can tell that it
stretched a little bit, but other than that, there's
no real wear that we found.

So we wanted to optimize the
process after we concluded that leather was our material.

And so we processed about
1.5 liters at a time, and we did a whole bunch
of different experiments.

We really focused on the
optimal tightness in the molino, and we did this by
looking at the percent that was husked and
the broken grains

and how fast we
could do 1.5 liters. And then we also attached five
washers to the side knobs.

This is allowed for
stability, it allowed us to better control, the
spacing between the metal and the leather, so we could
really optimize our tightness.

So this is the data from
our experimentation, so we found that using
the one piece of leather, we get 94% to 96% husked,
which is really good.

And so our optimal outcome was
1% of unattached, four to five turns out.

Looking at our original
project specifications, we found that this was
very comparable to what

we have wanted, and
the durability we are positive about a
lot of about 160 pounds.

So we estimated that
was our minimum. So our final conclusion is that
one piece of leather unattached

to molino is at
best, 4.5 to 5 turns, but the user can
vary that depending

on what they want as broken
versus dehusked grains. It's very minimal cost.

It's about $0.50 per insert. It's durable. Again, we expected more
molino, but not too much,

and it's not toxic. GUST SPEAKER 7:
So now that you've heard a little bit of the
decisions behind the process,

I just want to take a little bit
through of what it might look like for someone
that's in the community and what they would have to do
to be able to use this process.

So first, they would have to
get a hold of a piece of leather and cut it to the donut shape
that would fit into the shaft.

And if the molino body
wasn't set up already, they would put it on
the stand and proceed

to put the leather on
the shaft and put that into three of the
main body and then

continue by adding the
reservoir up on top as well as the handle on the side.

Then the next thing would
be to add these washers so that this brace can hold
the shaft in the main body,

but it can still
be tightened enough and still leave enough space
for the leather to fit inside.

Then they would turn
the knob all the way in and then turn out the
specified 4.5 to 5 turns,

or according to
their preference, whether they wanted more broken
rice or more unhusked rice

and would then crank away and
put the rice in and process.

And from there,
separate the husks from the grains by winnowing it,
using their preferred method.

And from there,
just as a side note, we also found that when
we're doing our more detailed

experiments, we found that-- or to separate the broken
rice versus the whole grains, we found that when we were
shaking it back and forth

in the sieves, the unhusked
rice actually came up to the top

just because it's a
little bit larger. And so that gave a natural
separation between the ones

that still have the husks
on and the ones that didn't. And so what we're
going to be suggesting

is to put the winnowed
rice into a container and shake it back and
forth a little bit.

And from there, the rice
will then collect to the top and gets to be able
to scoop it out, and that's what gives us our
96% efficiency, and that's

the other contribution
to the process. So from there, the
rice is ready to go,

and they would just have to
be washed before it's eaten. So we just like to thank
[INAUDIBLE] and D-Lab staff

for helping us out and for
Will Floyd from Windmill Rice or giving us our rice.

So if you guys
have any questions, just thank you for listening.

AUDIENCE: And I would
say you did a good job. GUEST SPEAKER 6: How
available is leather-- GUST SPEAKER 7: So we visited--

or I guess I didn't. These two went to the-- GUEST SPEAKER 4:
We went to a store

in one of the town's
nearby these communities, and it was a shoe store
that just sold leather

in massive quantities,
so it is available. And the community partner
that we worked with, actually,

they were the ones
who brought us there, so they would be able to
supply the communities with the leather.

AUDIENCE: What fraction of your
rice remains broken at the end? GUEST SPEAKER 5:
Probably about a third.

I mean, what we were
really concerned with was how much-- like the
percentage of husk,

like the husk dries because
you can eat broken rice. It's not as nice.

You would rather not eat
it, but for the most part, we would rather err on
the side of dehusking

most of the rice versus
leaving at husked at all. So about a third of it
was probably broken.

We lost maybe about
between 5% and 10%

of it was just like
sand, grainy sized. So it was pretty good.

GUEST SPEAKER 6:
We have something that people can
adjust the turns to, so if they would prefer
having more husked rice

and just pull it out
themselves, then it would probably be less
broken rice because it's not going to be as tight. It's not going to be
crushing it as much.

GUEST SPEAKER 4: And
something also, we learned from the
community partners that when they currently
bring it to a mill

to have it dehusked, and
when they get it back, some pieces do still husks on
and some pieces are broken.

So what they currently have
is something similar to what [INAUDIBLE].

AUDIENCE: And they could
theoretically cycle the non-husked,
stone rice in and-- GUEST SPEAKER 5: Yeah, just
process it back through.

That's what we found was
really nice about it. We weren't quite expecting this,
but when we were shaking it, well, look at that.

All the husked rice is
right in the center. So you just scooped
it all out, just put it back with the rice that
hasn't been processed yet.

AUDIENCE: This sieve that
you used, are those-- GUST SPEAKER 7: Yeah, so
the fact that this is sieved

is irrelevant. We just happened to use a sieve. AUDIENCE: You were
using the sieve

to take out the broken rice. GUST SPEAKER 7: Exactly. Yeah. And so it would just be a
fairly shallow container.

So the fact that it's a
sieve doesn't really-- it isn't the one that's
causing it to separate. GUEST SPEAKER 5: But
we did realize though,

it was really important
that the bottom was relatively flat and sturdy and
that the sides wouldn't bend.

So you wouldn't want
a plastic container because you can't get the right
motion for that shaking back

and forth for it to separate. So it felt kind of like-- GUST SPEAKER 7: But
we just, actually, used the same container that we
were winnowing in, so I mean,

we don't have the huge
platters that they use, but that would
definitely be something

that we'll suggest
to [INAUDIBLE] and have them try it
out to see if it works.

JESSICA ARTILES: Good
afternoon, everyone. Thank you for coming. Our group project is Barrel
on Fire, Charcoal Desire.

My name is Jessica Artiles and
along with Vivian Dean and Kurt Swoll, we went to Sabana
Grande in Nicaragua,

and we reintroduced and
re-helped the women make charcoal out of agri waste.

So for context of charcoal
in the communities in Sabana Grande, in 2009, a
professor, Amy Banzaert,

visited the community
and introduces charcoal. Over the years, the
knowledge was lost. The women lost practice.

They had challenges. They didn't yield briquettes. When they tried to
make it, they were getting less than 10
briquettes per yield.

So we went this spring
break to Nicaragua. We reintroduced the process
to four women, whom we now

call the Charcoal Captains. And when we were there,
our yield of burns

were coming up to around
80 because of her burn. Since then, we came
back, we redesigned

the charcoal-making process. We made the
innovations, send them back our feedback and results.

And when they've done
it with our new design, they're getting up to 110
briquettes per burning.

So the project is looking
commercially viable for them. They're looking at
making the charcoal for the restaurant that's on
site to fuel and to cook with.

They're going to
be making charcoal to sell to the community,
and they're actually going to be displaying
it in their community

service in May on how to make
charcoal and how to sell it.

KURT SWOLL: So the
way that we identified the problem was looking at
the current charcoal-burning

process, it requires
lighting this oil drum on fire, which is
packed with dry biomass

and then sealing both
the bottom and the top. So this process, right now,
with the barrel standing

on top of the three bricks,
is optimized for cost. So this is the most
low cost way to do it.

However, we felt like we could
add improvements that would be justified in their cost.

Because this has
two main problems. One is the issue
of heat exposure, so the user actually has to
get quite close to the barrel

to be able to kick out the
bricks from the bottom, and the second is the
safety issue, where

in sealing the bottom of the
barrel, you have to tip it, and this could result
in some accidents.

JESSICA ARTILES: [INAUDIBLE]. KURT SWOLL: So as
you can see, there are flames coming out of
the bottom of the barrel,

as they're doing this, so
that's the heat problem. And then as they're

fell over and almost
landed on one of the women. So this is a safety
concern, and there was also

a lot of biomass to
the left of the barrel so it could have lit
all that on fire too.

VIVIAN DEAN: So how
do we solve this? Our solution consists
of a circular dugout, a slightly smaller in
circumference than the barrel.

And within that dugout
stands three air channels. And within each air channel are
two bricks that are embedded,

and the barrel simply
sits on top of the ground and on top of the bricks
for a very stable setup.

When we tested our
solution, we wanted to make sure that the biomass
can still be lit pretty easily through the bottom.

What we found was that
biomass, actually, it's a lot easier because
the air channels actually

block any wind that could
interfere with the process. We also calculated the size
of the air channel needed

to be to allow the
necessary airflow for a very thorough burn. You can see on the sides of the
barrel is sealed to the ground

except for by the air channels,
and because the barrel sits

on the ground level,
we eliminate the risk of having to tip over the barrel
or having to handle or move

the barrel while it's on fire. Eventually, you'll
need to cut off the air supply to the biomass
to allow it to carbonize,

and so the way we figured we
would seal these air channels is through these metal plates.

So the idea behind these
places for the user to be able to slide the

keeping a safe distance,
so that they're not exposed to the heat as much. And through several
design iterations,

this is our final

It's made out of one piece
of sheet metal, which is very readily
available in Nicaragua,

and the handle is made by
making slits in the sheet metal and curving it

available in Nicaragua as well.  So yeah, we just use metal
shears to cut the sheet metal

so it's pretty simple.  We have a video of

use of these new metal seals. [VIDEO PLAYBACK] - All right, add the link.

maintained a safe distance,

- [INAUDIBLE]. [END PLAYBACK] VIVIAN DEAN: And
that is our solution.

A big question that came

coming out of the

improve our solution
even more is to develop radiation shields. And the gold standard

is aluminum tin foil,
but we ruled this out because it is just too

be able to withstand the thermal

Here, you have window

it wouldn't justify the cost.

The heat reduction
wouldn't justify the cost. So you see in this graph is

on the x-axis, and

sheet or the window screen. And on the y-axis, you have

So where does this
leave our solution?

Well, we think that the dugout
and metal plate seals really represent kind of a sweet spot,
like in a range of solutions.

At the very top, you just
have the tip and kick method. And then you can
introduce the dugout

and just seal the
holes with sand, but that wouldn't give you
as much heat reduction.

they're trying to preserve.  And they have a
